title: How to Teach Your Toddler About Spring

steps.headline: Splash in the puddles.
steps.description: Have them put on their rain boots and allow them to splash in the melting snow. Explain to them that when the weather gets warmer, all of the snow (or ice) melts into water, creating puddles.

steps.headline: Stand still and listen.
Examine trees.
steps.description: Use a specific tree for the entire spring season to pinpoint a timeline of when the flowers bloom. Track a chart and teach them that with warmer weather, the flowers and grass starts to grow and bloom again.

steps.headline: Make a bird feeder.
steps.description: The easiest method with a toddler is to use a simple milk carton and hang out in the backyard.

steps.headline: Plant something in a garden.
Recycle clothespins.
steps.description: Transfer them into caterpillars or butterflies and paint them with appropriate colors. Use tissue paper, glue, markers, construction paper, and other assorted craft items. Ask them where each one of them spends their time during the Spring.

steps.headline: Suggest Spring themed things to draw.
steps.description:
Know that you may have to draw a simple test drawing for them or have a prepared printout in front of them. Some suggestions for the season to draw could be:
Trees
Flowers
Sun
Eggs (for Easter)

steps.headline: Make a dirt, land, and air drawing.
steps.description: Cut out magazine pictures or print online images of animals. Ask your toddler where each animal usually spends its time (such as birds in the air, earthworms underground, and squirrels on land).

steps.headline: Utilize Spring themed worksheets.
steps.description: Focus on counting animals, flowers, and other season friendly items out loud.

steps.headline: Make Easter shaped cookies.
steps.description: Teach them the common Spring colors, such as green, yellow, and light blue. Use these colors in icing or frosting on the homemade cookies you make together.

tyn: Dot markers (e.g. Do-A-Dot), or thick-tipped kids’ markers
sentences: Enjoying the Outdoors Splash in the puddles.
Have them put on their rain boots and allow them to splash in the melting snow.
Explain to them that when the weather gets warmer, all of the snow (or ice) melts into water, creating puddles.
Stand still and listen.
Have them tell you what they hear, such as birds, squirrels, planes, vehicles going by, and other noises.
Teach them that when spring comes around, the birds and other animals also come out and play.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Examine trees.
Use a specific tree for the entire spring season to pinpoint a timeline of when the flowers bloom.
Track a chart and teach them that with warmer weather, the flowers and grass starts to grow and bloom again.
Make a bird feeder.
The easiest method with a toddler is to use a simple milk carton and hang out in the backyard.
Plant something in a garden.
Start getting them interacting with the world by getting dirty the natural way.
Give them a plastic shovel and encourage them to dig a small hole in the ground.

Have them go out and spray the plant throughout Spring.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Creating Educational Lessons Recycle clothespins.
Transfer them into caterpillars or butterflies and paint them with appropriate colors.
Use tissue paper, glue, markers, construction paper, and other assorted craft items.
Ask them where each one of them spends their time during the Spring.
Suggest Spring themed things to draw.
Know that you may have to draw a simple test drawing for them or have a prepared printout in front of them.

Some suggestions for the season to draw could be:
Trees
Flowers
Sun
Eggs (for Easter) Make a dirt, land, and air drawing.
Cut out magazine pictures or print online images of animals.
Ask your toddler where each animal usually spends its time (such as birds in the air, earthworms underground, and squirrels on land).
Utilize Spring themed worksheets.
Focus on counting animals, flowers, and other season friendly items out loud.
Make Easter shaped cookies.
Teach them the common Spring colors, such as green, yellow, and light blue.
Use these colors in icing or frosting on the homemade cookies you make together.
